key_points: Hackers known as Babuk infiltrated the D.C. police department's computer network, posting hundreds of internal documents.
The document release includes daily intelligence briefing papers of the police chief and information on street crews and threats following the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
Babuk's data dump came after breakdown of negotiations with District officials, demanding money in exchange for not releasing more data.
District officials have closed off Babuk’s entry point but haven't commented on negotiations or confirmed the posted documents' authenticity.
Babuk claims to have posted all stolen files and shared their hacking tool with other groups.
Cybersecurity experts caution that paying ransom doesn't guarantee safety from further demands or sale of stolen data.
Stolen files range from a job applicant's résumé to lists of gang suspects and witnesses to crimes.
D.C. Police Chief Robert J. Contee III assured affected individuals they would be contacted and offered guidance.
Police union chairman Greggory Pemberton criticizes the District's handling of sensitive information and calls for an inspector general investigation.
Release of gang files poses danger by potentially exposing suspects not under arrest, witnesses, and details on gang territories.
spokespersons: Robert J. Contee III (Chief, D.C. Police)
Raj Samani (Chief Scientist and Cybersecurity Fellow, McAfee Corp.)
